If you grew up anytime in the last 49 years
you almost certainly can tell me how to get
to Sesame Street.

This show, first aired is 1969, is an icon
in children’s educational TV, even more

so than Half as Interesting, teaching kids
about grammar, math, history, and even personal
issues like divorce, tolerance, and death.

The big boss of Sesame Street is Big Bird
as he’s usually the the one asking questions

and learning lessons both for his sake and
the sake of the audience which is why it's

particularly troubling that Big Bird narrowly
avoided total calamity and I'm not talking
about repeated attempts to gut PBS' funding.

I’m talking about how Big Bird, along with
the medium sized human inside him, nearly
died in a space shuttle.

NASA's space shuttle program was designed
to accomplish necessary routine orbital flights

and was operational from 1981 to 2011 under
the name "Space Transportation System."

It was particularly exciting for NASA because
the shuttles were the only manned-spacecrafts

that could be reused once returned to earth—they
wouldn’t become orbital paperweights like
other rockets.

At the same time, once the Apollo program
wrapped up interest in space exploration dwindled

so, in an effort to increase interest, NASA
started approaching people outside of NASA
to go to space.

NASA’s overlord is, of course, Congress
so in an expensive way of asking them for

more money NASA sent then-Senator Jake Garn
and then-Representative Bill Nelson into orbit.

Having each served in the military their credentials
were not that different than non-politician

astronauts and being from Utah and Florida
respectively, I assume they were only too
happy to leave Earth for a while.

After this proved somewhat successful, NASA
wanted to open the occasional orbital flight

to other civilians and established the Space
Flight Participant Program.

Big Bird's performer, Caroll Spinney, was
the first invited to orbit the earth by the
program in 1986.

Though, they didn't want Spinney to go as
himself.
They wanted him to go as Big Bird.

This is because NASA wanted to focus on bringing
civilians who were known as creative and educational,

and wanted space travel to seem more approachable
and interesting to the average Joe so applicants

to the program included hundreds of reporters
like Walter Cronkite.

Still, NASA sent the invitation to Caroll
Spinney as they wanted the shuttle program

to seem exciting and fun to kids and teach
them that they too can go to space if they

become an eight foot anthropomorphic bird,
I guess.

Spinney may have been a perfect fit but Big
Bird was not.

The Big Bird puppet is over eight feet tall,
and it turns out that they didn’t plan to

fly grotesquely oversized canary birds when
designing the Space Shuttle.

There’d be next to no space at all for Spinney
let alone the Big Bird puppet.

So, much like Spinney, NASA’s original talks
to get the looming plumage of Big Bird into

the shuttle didn't end up going anywhere,
and NASA turned to a new initiative where
they'd send teachers into space.

In 1985, 114 applicants from the “Teachers
in Space Project” were sent to a conference

in Washington, DC that lasted a week where
they would learn the ins and outs of space
travel.

From there, ten teachers were chosen to undergo
more training and interviewing before being
narrowed down to one.

The teacher who would replace Big Bird on
the Space Shuttle was Christa McAuliffe, a
social studies teacher from Concord, New Hampshire.

If you recognize that name then you know where
this story is going.

McAuliffe was chosen out of over eleven thousand
applicants to ride with the six-member crew
on the Space Shuttle Challenger.

Tragically, on January 26th, 1986, 73 seconds
after liftoff, the Challenger exploded killing
everyone on board.

This was due to an external tank explosion
that was the end result of complications arising
from the unusual coldness on the launch day.

The Challenger explosion is regarded as one
of the biggest tragedies of our time and the

Teachers in Space Project ended immediately,
though, NASA did follow up the project with

the Educator Astronaut Project which required
teachers to leave the classroom permanently
to join NASA.

If Big Bird had been on that Space Shuttle,
which was at one point the plan, such a public

death would have required Sesame Street to
retire the character.

The show is no stranger to hard-hitting themes,
but still, the idea of Big Bird never coming

back seems like something a bit too hard for
the child audience to swallow.

Thankfully, Big Bird’s still around and
living in his nest just behind 123 Sesame
Street.
